title: What do you think will happen in World War III? - Quora

response.answer_text: There seems to be a general belief that if a global conflict erupts, it will inevitably turn nuclear. That’s certainly a possibility—and a truly terrifying one—but I can envision scenarios in which a widespread global conflict occurs without nuclear weapons being deployed. It comes down to what you mean by “world war”. If we go by the first two world wars—or three, because there are good arguments that the Seven Years War, in the late Eighteenth Century, was fought in many parts of the globe and constitutes a “world war”—then WW3 could involve a conventional conflict that happens to involve fighting in many parts of the world. In WW2, for example, the bulk of the fighting occurred in Europe and the western Soviet Union, North Africa and the Mediterranean, parts of China and Southeast Asia, and much of the Pacific basin excluding the Americas (yes, I know the Japanese attacked the U.S. with a submarine, and some incendiary balloons), and much of the northern Atlantic basin. That’s certainly a big chunk of the world, but it excludes most of North and South America, most of Africa and much of Asia. So, we can confidently say a “world war” needs to have conflicts occur around the world, but not literally involving all of it. Given this, we could have a “world war” involving the United States and some allies on one side; the other side would likely have to involve China and/or Russia, or these two nations would need to be involved in some way, anyway. No other nations really have the means, or the potential means, to project power very far from their homeland, so a conflict with any of them would likely be regional (but could escalate). Such a conflict could involve combat in places like the Korean Peninsula, parts of Europe, parts of the Middle East, perhaps parts of Africa and southern Asia, and the Atlantic and Pacific ocean basins. The scale of destruction would probably be such that such a conflict would be intense, but of relatively short duration; I doubt that we’d see a years-long conflict like previous world wars, that heavily engages the combatants economically and socially for long periods of time. So what would be the consequences? Well, if we assume a relatively brief and intense conflict in several theaters, that doesn’t involve the deployment of nuclear weapons, then we’d likely see: -a breakdown in global trade. The global economy would suffer terribly; many national economies would collapse and we’d certainly see global recession and possibly depression. We would probably suffer through severe economic disruption for years; -the collapse of global telecommunications. Between infrastructure damage, and the possible use of weapons designed to destroy satellites, blind sensors, etc. we’d likely find our cellular and other networks severely disrupted. Some parts of the world would fare worse, others not so much and would probably recover more quickly; -a complete disruption of global politics and diplomacy. Depending on the outcome of the conflict, governments could collapse, revolutions could occur, countries could fragment and new and (at least initially) unstable national entities could arise. For example, if Russia fought and was on the losing side, the existing government could fall, while ethnic and nationalist tensions could cause parts of the country to declare independence. It might take years, or even decades, for anything like a stable global political climate to re-emerge; -severe environmental damage. Damage to infrastructure could lead to chemical and other spills; the destruction of nuclear-powered ships and submarines could leave uncontained nuclear reactors and their fuel “at large” in the world’s oceans. Even the destruction of conventionally-fueled ships could lead to massive fuel and oil spills. Cleaning these up would probably not be an immediate priority—certainly while the conflict is ongoing—and may take a long time to clean up after the cessation of hostilities; -opportunists—both nation-states, and non-state actors like terrorist and other groups—would likely take advantage of the chaos to advance all sorts of agendae. If the major powers are distracted from regional tensions like the Koreas or the Middle East, then those players may make moves that erupt into regional wars (which would, themselves, have all sorts of knock-on effects). I could probably go on, but the bottom line really is that, even if a single nuclear weapon isn’t detonated, a global conflict today would be MASSIVELY disruptive, VERY painful in many ways and have effects that would last for decades. Our world may LOOK largely the same, but it would probably be a very different, much poorer and far more unstable place.
